div.head:
Embleme 41. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Adonis is killd by a Boar, to whome Venus hasting tinged the
Roses with her blood.

lg.l: Myrrha, conspiring with her Sire, gave breath
To th' fair Adonis, tushd by a Boar to death:
Fond Venus runns, with thorne in foot, which bled,
And therewith tingd the lilly Roses red;
The Goddesse weeps, the Syrians can't refraine,
Hee's layd amongst the lettice being Slayne

div.head: Discourse 4i.
div.ab:
How improperly some of the Mythologists resolve the Allegory of-
Adonis, and ascribe him sometimes to the Sunne, the Boare, by which
hee was slayne, to a hard winter, sometimes to the seed of wheat,-
which is six moneths with Proserpina under the earth, and as many
above the earth with Venus, is elswhere sufficiently explained and
refuted by us. Here wee doe with the consent of all men declare the
Philosophicall Sunne to be meant by Adonis: From whence the Versicle:
Omnia sunt idem, Dionysus, Sol, et Adonis:
And Orphens:------Qui vario Cætaris nomine Adoni,
Germinum et idem author, pariter puer atq puella.
All which are by noe means to be understood of the cælestiall, but-
Philosophicall Sunne; for this expresseth both sexes, that not: Soe all
so they attribute the very same thing to Dionysus, and the Sunne,-
as to Adonis, and on the contrary, as allso to Osiris. Adonis is killd by a
Boare, that is, by Acetum acerrimum, or the solutive water, which hath
terrible teeth like a boar, with which hee tusheth Adonis; because the-
Philosophicall Sol is mortalls wounded by that boar, loosened in the
members and cutt of; But Venus endeavours to helpe her Paramour,-
who being dead, shee layd him amongst Lettices, and watchd him. After
the same manner is Osiris killd by Typhon, and cut into severall peices,
which Isis, the wife of Osiris, gathered up, and being joynd together bu
ryed. The same mourning, which followed the death of Osiris every-
year in Ægypt, was allso celebrated after the death of Adonis in Syria
and the bordering kingdoms; where for some dayes weeping and wailing
being heard, afterwards were signs of joy given, and dancing, as if hee,
that was dead, now lived anew being conveyed to heaven: From whence
arose the vanity of their religion or heathenish superstition, which-
grew to an excessive height, the Devill giving occasion, and procuring
false miracles. Adonis was (as they feigne) borne of Cinyre King of
Cyprus, and Myrrha his daughter, hee is sayd to be borne in incæst (if
history be considered) wicked, if an allegory, not unlawfull, but prin
cipally necessary: For if the mother and Sonne, or the father and-
daughter be not joynd together, and an offspring produced from thence,
nothing is perfected in this art. For here, the nearer the man and
wife are one to the other in blood, in the first degree of consan
guinity, or second, the more fruitfull they are, and on the con
trary, the more remote, the more unfruitfull, which is not tolerable
in the matrimony of men. For this cause Œdypus marryd his owne
mother, Jupiter his Sister, soe allso Osiris, Saturne, Sol, the red
servant, Gabritius; Sol (in a Metaphor of Belinus in the Rosary)-
Discourse 4i.
speaks thus of Adonis, that is, of himselfe: Know yee, that my father Sol
hath given mee power above all power, and cloathed mee with the gar
ment of glory: And a little after: For I am his onely Sonne and more
like my father, Ct: I divest my servants of their power and nature,-
and cloath them with my beautifull splendour and light (which my
father gave mee) in all their works: For I am excellent, who doe exalt
and depresse all things, and none of my servants is above mee, but one,-
who is permitted to be repugnant and contrary to mee: And hee destroyes
mee, yet destroyes not my nature: And hee is Saturne, who separates all
my parts: Afterwards I goe to my mother, who gathers together all my-
divided and separated members: I illuminate all those things that-
appertaine to mee, and cause light to appear openly in the way from
my father Saturne, as allso from my mother, who is an enemy to mee.
The words hitherto spoken are soe clear, as to discusse darkenesse from
the eyes of the mind even to him that is but meanly conversant in-
the reading of authors, and discover the light of the Sunne, which is
abundantly perspicuous in the cohærencyes insinuated of things and per
sons: For those things which are true, though shaded under the veyle
of an allegory, doe consent in wonderfull harmony one with another,-
but those things which are false are repugnant, and inconsistent with
themselves, and others. . . . . . . . .
